snippet: Many restaurants treat their workers fairly, but it is not hard for unscrupulous businesses to find people desperate enough to do work for less than what the law requires.
abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column notes many restaurants treat their workers fairly, whether out of a sense of decency or the self-interest of having a loyal work force and willingly pay minimum wage; says yet so many immigrants are willing to do this work that it is not hard for unscrupulous businesses to find people desperate enough to do it for less than what the law requires.
lead_paragraph: Many restaurants treat their workers fairly, but it is not hard for unscrupulous businesses to find people desperate enough to do work for less than what the law requires.

headline.main: When Minimum Wage Rises, Many Are Left Looking Up at It
headline.print_headline: When Minimum Wage Rises, Many Are Left Looking Up at It
